questions.question_html: In \triangle ABC, the measure of\angle B is 21^{o} less than the angle of \angle A multiplied by 4. The measure of \angle C is 1^{o} more than the measure of \angle A multiplied by 5. Determine the measure of each interior angle and each exterior angle of \triangle ABC.
questions.question: In `$\triangle$` ABC, the measure of`$\angle B$` is `$21^{o}$` less than the angle of `$\angle A$` multiplied by 4.   The measure of `$\angle C$` is `$1^{o}$` more than the measure of `$\angle A$` multiplied by 5.   Determine the measure of each interior angle and each exterior angle of `$\triangle ABC$`.
questions.answer:
Vertex  `$A$` inerior angle: `$20^\circ$` , exterior angle: `$160^\circ$`

Vertex  `$B$` inerior angle: `$59^\circ$` , exterior angle: `$121^\circ$`

Vertex  `$C$` inerior angle: `$101^\circ$` , exterior angle: `$79^\circ$`
questions.answer_html:
Vertex A inerior angle: 20^\circ , exterior angle: 160^\circ

Vertex B inerior angle: 59^\circ , exterior angle: 121^\circ

Vertex C inerior angle: 101^\circ , exterior angle: 79^\circ

questions.question_html:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

  • rhombus
questions.question:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

* rhombus
questions.answer: `$(5,0):$` The diagonals had to be perpendicular and bisecting.
questions.answer_html: (5,0): The diagonals had to be perpendicular and bisecting.

questions.question_html:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

  • isosceles trapezoid
questions.question:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

* isosceles trapezoid
questions.answer:
`$(11, 0)$`: The diagonals had to be congruent and intersect to form
two pairs of equal line segments.
questions.answer_html: (11, 0): The diagonals had to be congruent and intersect to form two pairs of equal line segments.

questions.question_html:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

  • kite
questions.question:
Each quadrilateral ABCD below has these three vertices: A(0, 0), B(3, 4), and C(8, 4). Use diagonal properties to identify the coordinates of the fourth vertex D in each case. Explain your method.

* kite
questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., `$(6, -2)$`; the diagonals had to be
perpendicular and one had to bisect the other.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., (6, -2); the diagonals had to be perpendicular and one had to bisect the other.

questions.question_html: Match each pair of diagonals with its quadrilateral. Explain your reasoning.
questions.question:
Match each pair of diagonals with its quadrilateral. Explain your reasoning.

#2764
questions.answer:
a) iii); perpendicular, congruent, bisecting

b) v); perpendicular, bisecting

c) i); congruent, divided congruently

d) ii); bisecting

e) vi); perpendicular, one bisects the other

f) iv); congruent, bisecting
questions.answer_html:
a) iii); perpendicular, congruent, bisecting

b) v); perpendicular, bisecting

c) i); congruent, divided congruently

d) ii); bisecting

e) vi); perpendicular, one bisects the other

f) iv); congruent, bisecting

materials.name: 7.4 Reasoning About Triangle and Quadrilateral Properties

questions.question_html: Predict whether a polygon’s sides are all equal if its interior angles are all equal. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.question: Predict whether a polygon’s sides are all equal if its interior angles are all equal. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all sides equal.
A counterexample is a rectangle. All the angles are `$90$`°, but the sides
are not all equal.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all sides equal. A counterexample is a rectangle. All the angles are 90°, but the sides are not all equal.

questions.question_html: Predict whether a polygon’s interior angles are all equal if its sides are all equal. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.question: Predict whether a polygon’s interior angles are all equal if its sides are all equal. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all angles
equal. A counterexample is a rhombus. All the sides are equal length.
but the angles are not all equal.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all angles equal. A counterexample is a rhombus. All the sides are equal length. but the angles are not all equal.

questions.question_html: Create a conjecture to predict the number of diagonals from any one vertex of a convex polygon with n sides. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.question: Create a conjecture to predict the number of diagonals from any one vertex of a convex polygon with n sides. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict there are `$n - 3$` diagonals from each
vertex in an `$n$`-sided polygon. I think my conjecture is true. All my
examples support it. A triangle has `$0$` diagonals, a square has `$1$` diagonal.
a pentagon has `$2$` diagonals, and a hexagon has `$3$` diagonals.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict there are n - 3 diagonals from each vertex in an n-sided polygon. I think my conjecture is true. All my examples support it. A triangle has 0 diagonals, a square has 1 diagonal. a pentagon has 2 diagonals, and a hexagon has 3 diagonals.

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “If the midsegments of a quadrilateral form a square, then the quadrilateral is itself a square.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “If the midsegments of a quadrilateral form a square, then the quadrilateral is itself a square.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is false. For a counterexample, I constructed an
isosceles trapezoid with bimedians forming a square.

#3515
questions.answer_html: The conjecture is false. For a counterexample, I constructed an isosceles trapezoid with bimedians forming a square.

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “The medians of a triangle always intersect at exactly one point.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “The medians of a triangle always intersect at exactly one point.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is true. 

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew several triangles
using The Geometer's Sketchpad and then drew their medians. The
medians for each triangle always intersected in one point. All my
examples—an equilateral triangle, an isosceles triangle, `$3$` right
triangle, and two scalene triangles—supported the conjecture
questions.answer_html:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew several triangles using The Geometer's Sketchpad and then drew their medians. The medians for each triangle always intersected in one point. All my examples—an equilateral triangle, an isosceles triangle, 3 right triangle, and two scalene triangles—supported the conjecture

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “It is always possible to draw a circle through all four vertices in a rectangle.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “It is always possible to draw a circle through all four vertices in a rectangle.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew different
rectangles using The Geometer’s Sketchpad. Then I looked for possible
circles. The centre of the circle was always at the intersection of the
diagonals of the rectangle. I intersected the diagonals of every
rectangle and then drew a circle with a centre at the intersection
point. I always found one that intersected each vertex.
questions.answer_html:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew different rectangles using The Geometer’s Sketchpad. Then I looked for possible circles. The centre of the circle was always at the intersection of the diagonals of the rectangle. I intersected the diagonals of every rectangle and then drew a circle with a centre at the intersection point. I always found one that intersected each vertex.

questions.question_html: Billy claims that the sum of the interior angles of a regular octagon is 900^o. Is he correct? Justify your decision.
questions.question: Billy claims that the sum of the interior angles of a regular octagon is `$900^o$`.   Is he correct?  Justify your decision.
questions.answer:
He is incorrect.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I know the sum of the interior angles of an `$n$`-gon is `$180 \times (n-2)$` degrees. This works out to `$1080^\circ$` for an octagon.
questions.answer_html:
He is incorrect.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I know the sum of the interior angles of an n-gon is 180 \times (n-2) degrees. This works out to 1080^\circ for an octagon.

questions.question_html:
a) Calculate the measure of each interior angle of a regular 25- gon.

b) What is the measure of each exterior angle?
questions.question:
a) Calculate the measure of each interior angle of a regular 25-
gon.

b) What is the measure of each exterior angle?
questions.answer:
**wrong video or wrong question** 


a) `$2$` is subtracted from `$n$` to give the number of triangles that are
formed by the diagonals of the `$n$`-gon.

b) `$(n-2)$` is multiplied by `$180^\circ$`, because there are `$180^\circ$` in each of the triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the `$n$`-gon.
questions.answer_html:
wrong video or wrong question

a) 2 is subtracted from n to give the number of triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the n-gon.

b) (n-2) is multiplied by 180^\circ, because there are 180^\circ in each of the triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the n-gon.

#2620

**a)** Determine the length of the bimedian joining the two non—parallel sides.

**b)** The distance between the parallel sides is 12 cm. How far is the bimedian from each?
questions.answer_html:
a) 26 cm

b) 6 cm

questions.question_html:
Draw a circle and plot four points on it. Join adjacent points to form a quadrilateral. Extend a side at each vertex.

a) Compare each interior angle with the exterior angle at the opposite vertex. What do you notice?

b) Repeat your angle measurements for a quadrilateral whose vertices cannot all be plotted on one circle.

c) Form a conjecture from your observations, and explain how to test it.
questions.question:
Draw a circle and plot four points on it. Join adjacent points to form a quadrilateral. Extend a side at each vertex.

#2619

**a)** Compare each interior angle with the exterior angle at the opposite vertex. What do you notice?

**b)** Repeat your angle measurements for a quadrilateral whose vertices cannot all be plotted on one circle.

**c)** Form a conjecture from your observations, and explain how to test it.
questions.answer:
a) They are equal.

b) They are not equal.

c) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., Conjecture: Every quadrilateral whose vertices lie on a circle has supplementary opposite angles, and these
are the only quadrilaterals that do. I could test this conjecture by
drawing many quadrilaterals. I would divide them into `$2$` groups.
One group would have quadrilaterals whose vertices lie on a circle.
The other group would have all the other quadrilaterals. Then I
could measure the angles For each quadrilateral.
questions.answer_html:
a) They are equal.

b) They are not equal.

c) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., Conjecture: Every quadrilateral whose vertices lie on a circle has supplementary opposite angles, and these are the only quadrilaterals that do. I could test this conjecture by drawing many quadrilaterals. I would divide them into 2 groups. One group would have quadrilaterals whose vertices lie on a circle. The other group would have all the other quadrilaterals. Then I could measure the angles For each quadrilateral.
